required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Neurocognitive Optimization and Enhancement for Brain Health and Performance

lead_sponsor.agency: Walter Reed Army Institute of Research (WRAIR)

clinical_study.source: Walter Reed Army Institute of Research (WRAIR)

brief_summary.textblock: Brain-Physical Optimization Conditioning (B-POC) aims to enhance physical performance by expanding the traditional focus of endurance training from purely physical training to the domain of cognitive endurance (Staiano et al., 2015; Dallaway et al., 2017). The current study seeks to isolate neurocognitive mechanisms of performance, particularly under high stress (e.g., physical or cognitive load) conditions, and to develop corresponding cognitive optimization tools.

detailed_description.textblock: Brain-Physical Optimization Conditioning (B-POC) aims to enhance physical performance by expanding the traditional focus of endurance training from purely physical training to the domain of cognitive endurance (Staiano et al., 2015; Dallaway et al., 2017). B-POC uses an acute mentally fatiguing task during routine exercise with the aim of optimizing the effects of physical endurance (e.g., aerobic exercise). B-POC differs from other types of cognitive training by increasing the cognitive demands of a specific concurrent task rather than teaching a cognitive strategy and relying on task transfer effects. Similar to strengthening a muscle, cognitive trainings may be one means of increasing Soldier's cognitive capacity and improving performance (Walton et al., 2018).

primary_outcome.description: This test requires participants to run on a treadmill with incremental increases in grade (1% increase every minute) until the given work rate (speed) cannot be maintained, and thus, there is cessation of the exercise. The work rate will be calculated from their last 2 mile run time.

arm_group.description: aerobic exercise [heartrate range (HRR) 70-75% of max HR, on spin bike] and a computerized high-load task for 60 minutes, 3 times per week, for 6 weeks
aerobic exercise [heartrate range (HRR) 70-75% of max HR, on spin bike] and a computerized low-load task for 60 minutes, 3 times per week, for 6 weeks

intervention.description: aerobic exercise [heartrate range (HRR) 70-75% of max HR, on spin bike] and a computerized high-load task for 60 minutes, 3 times per week, for 6 weeks
aerobic exercise [heartrate range (HRR) 70-75% of max HR, on spin bike] and a computerized low-load task for 60 minutes, 3 times per week, for 6 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy active duty Soldiers
- 18-40 years old
- Available for study duration
Exclusion Criteria:
- Failure of an Army Physical Fitness/Combat Test (APFT/ACFT) test
- On a physical profile that prevents them from 1) engaging in intense aerobic exercise, 2) running on a treadmill, 3) riding the stationary bike, and 4) performing a cognitive task on a computer screen.
- Medically non-deployable
- Impaired cognitive function due to medication, injury or illness,
- Have been advised by a medical professional not to engage in aerobic exercise
- Are a pregnant female
